participants.participant: Robert P. Connolly, Managing Director and General Counsel
Paul L. Audet, Managing Director and Chief Financial Officer
Laurence D. Fink, Chief Executive Officer and Chairman

plist.p: Good morning. My name is Regina and I'll be your conference facility today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the BlackRock Incorporated Fourth Quarter 2007 Earnings Teleconference. Our hosts for today's call will be Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Laurence D. Fink; Chief Financial Officer, Paul L. Audet; and General Counsel, Robert P. Connolly. All lines have been place on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question and answer period. Thank you. Mr. Connolly, you may begin your conference.

Thank you. Good morning, everyone. Before Larry and Paul make their remarks, I want to point out that during the course of this conference call, we may make a number of forward-looking statements. We call to your attention the fact that BlackRock's actual results may differ from these statements. And as you know, BlackRock has filed with the SEC reports, which lists some of the factors which may cause our results to differ materially from these sometimes. Finally BlackRock assumes no duty to and does not undertake to update any forward-looking statements. With that I'll turn it other to Paul Audet, our Chief Financial Officer.

Good morning. As you can undoubtedly see in our release, BlackRock truly had a very successful year in 2007 as our financial results, new business generation, investment returns, client service, all exceeded our objectives going into 2007. Adjusted EPS for the fourth quarter at 252 exceeded analyst consensus by 18%, and this was due to strong contributions from our recurring operations. Obviously elevated performance fees and higher portfolio advisory revenue from BlackRock Solutions as we in effect took on a lot of risk management assignments due to these market conditions.

Fourth quarter adjusted EPS increased $0.23 or 10% from third quarter 2007 results, also largely from core operations as performance fees were essentially flat third to fourth quarter but net non-operating income declined approximately 27 million. Adjusted EPS for the 2007 fourth quarter and full year at 252 and 817, represented increases of 56 and 53% respectively over 2006.

Obviously this was also the first full quarter that we reported comparative results with the MLIM transaction as well as also the first full quarter of operations with Quellos. Accretion with respect to MLIM transaction based on our results on a full year basis, essentially doubled our initial estimates when we initially announced this transaction while the Quellos transaction contributed approximately $0.10 cents to earnings in the fourth quarter.

These are strong earnings reflect solid investment returns and favorable equity markets. Obviously the performance fee totals for the year at 350 million, of which 300 million was reported in the second half, to speak very solid investment results but also, also very, very global equity markets for us.

New business momentum was sustained despite a significant global integration effort, which covered not only MLIM but also Quellos in the fourth quarter as well as volatile market conditions. We experienced a 12% organic growth rate in AUM, including 7% organic growth in all our long-dated assets. We operate a leading cash management business which increased market share during 2007 as assets under management increased 32% or over 75 billion for the year. Most of this growth in cash management occurred in our 2a-7 mutual fund complex, which operated very effectively in these markets with no asset quality issues and very solid investment returns.

As many of you are aware, we have a very large institutional business. We did experience very similar and normal late quarter outflows and liquidity assets of approximately 8 billion. This usually happens because of a number of our large institutional clients regularly reposition their period end balance sheets. But at the same time liquidity assets are up almost 19 billion since we closed the books in December of 2007. I would also like to note one additional factor. Based on some information we have read recently, our assignment with Florida to support their process as a temporary assignment, and we do not report assets under management under temporary assignments.

So everyone should understand, while we are managing that process, right now we are participating in a very significant RFP that is out in the marketplace but we do not report any assets. The company during this period obviously continues to benefit from a diversified business mix and global footprint, which saw all of our product classes substantially increase new business over the full year, and international operations generated 38 billion in new business, and comprised and contributed approximately 50% of our pre-tax earnings for 2007.

We also generated positive operating leverage for the fourth quarter and full year, which was up approximately 1% for both periods. And as we noted in our release, that full year total of up 1% included approximately 92 million increase in intangible amortization. So on a real cash operating leverage basis, we were up approximately 3% year-over-year. The marketplace was very difficult in the second half. We did feel some implications, as you probably saw in the release. We incurred approximately 12 and $0.14 charges for the fourth quarter and full year respectively due to costs that we took to support two non 2a-7 private placement and hence cash funds. We worked very, very long to work with our clients on this. We believe that we can support those clients and in effect move all those assets, approximately 1.7, and in effect get all the clients' cash back during the 2008 timeframe. The company also recorded approximately $0.06 of impairment charges in the fourth quarter on seed investments in BlackRock sponsor-related CDOs.

I would note that a significant portion of our fourth quarter performance fees were generated by products with higher deferred compensation formulas. This resulted in lower current period or fourth quarter compensation expense as a percent of revenue, and will increase compensation expense in future periods. Most of these deferred compensations cover three-year vesting periods.

While we do not provide earnings guidance, we do have some objectives going into 2008. The firm belief that the long-dated AUM growth will be consistent with our 7% results achieved in 2007. Cash management flows will continue to be volatile, with opportunities for growth as the federal funds rate looks to be decreased over the first half to the year. but we could see some reduction of that growth as markets stabilize and we see some reallocation of 2007 flight-to-quality growth into other products.

Assuming a similar revenue mix for 2008, we would expect compensation of revenue ratios will rise approximately one half of 1%. This really ties directly to some of the large deferred compensation awards occurring at the end of the year. We continue to see positive operating leverage in our business going forward into 2008, but we also see significant opportunities in these markets. As you know, we will invest in our business in order to take advantage of those kinds of opportunities to serve clients better and provide opportunities for future growth.
On the whole, I just think you all saw a significant year. Obviously we are very, very proud of what we did here and I think the financial results show that. And with that I'll turn it over to Larry.

Thank you, Paul. Good morning everyone. It is very nice for me to be sitting here at BlackRock. We had an extraordinary year and we had an extraordinary quarter. I am very proud of the entire team as we navigated on behalf of our clients these markets. And we worked very diligently in trying to work with our clients in terms of helping them understand the severity of this credit problem in the marketplace and what the impact is in terms of their investment portfolios and in terms of what are the opportunities as a result of this allocations in the credit markets and all the other associated markets.

But I can say very loud and clear at the end of 2007 and looking into 2008, our model is working – having one platform representing products and equities in fixed income and alternatives. Working with our clients to try to solve problems comprehensively is a model that I believe is the model for the future. I believe clients worldwide are attracted to working alongside with BlackRock because we can provide them that comprehensiveness. And I think it is very, very important going forward as clients are struggling with portfolio allocation, they are struggling with liability issues, they are struggling with the understanding of their embedded assets that they have. They are struggling with what these credit issues mean to their portfolios, and they are struggling with the understanding of alternatives. And they are asking many questions as to what percent of alternatives should they have, and what should the mix of alternatives be.

Let me describe some of the things that we are particularly proud of in terms of what BlackRock represents to our clients. And that is the fulsome of our product mix. It sometimes, I find it somewhat disturbing when people still refer BlackRock as a fixed income manager, when they do that they just forget to understand who we are. They don't bother to look. But 34% of our assets today are in equities and balance 38% of our assets are fixed income, 23% is in cash management, and 5% alternatives. That is our hope, as I've suggested in other quarters that we would like to get our alternatives, a product mix, you know, between 7 and 10%. We hope to do that mostly through organic growth. And I think our fourth quarter in terms of our – the opportunities we saw in the alternative spaces showing the marketplace that we do have huge organic opportunities in the alternative space.

The other real differentiating facet of BlackRock today going into 2008, 64% of our assets are domestic, 36% are international, 31% of our client base is retail, 69% of our client base is institutional. I would call this a very good mix of types of businesses, and I believe this allows us to have the ability to navigate in the global market, to navigate in products, when one product is strong and another product is weak, we have the ability to navigate in good markets and bad markets and flat markets because the product mix, the geographic mix and the client mix.

I would like to also note that we continue to see huge opportunities in all our markets on be a global basis. We have been in the papers quite a bit related to some advisory assignments, particularly Florida. I could – I'm very proud to say that we have differentiated ourselves in 2007 and I think we'll continue to differentiate ourself in 2008 because the whole foundation of BlackRock in all products is our emphasis of risk management.

Having our BlackRock Solutions platform, which had the most outstanding year in their history in terms of integrating BlackRock on to one platform, and on top of that seeing a record number of clients enquiry in terms of Aladdin assignments and in terms of advisory assignments, is going to continue to drive BlackRock into 2008.

And that emphasis of risk, that differentiation does allow us to stand above most of our peers. We continue to expect BlackRock Solutions to have large scale opportunities in 2008. I'll say the biggest issue that's confronting us, more than ever before is making sure that we have the team in place to expand our presence. The greatest limiting factor for us in Solutions is that, is having the proper team on a global basis, the management structure. And so we are growing our people there, we are growing our staff, we are growing our presence. But we are not going to grow so fast that we are going to disrupt what I would call the one BlackRock culture, the one firm model. And so, we are trying to navigate the growth opportunities in these spaces with the idea of making sure that our One BlackRock model, our one culture, it permeates throughout all our businesses and making sure it is consistent in all our businesses. So it is an interesting time.

The enquiries, even in the first few weeks of this year are quite extraordinary in terms of client looking for long-term solutions, in terms of their balance sheet. We have had a number of new awards already in terms of working alongside clients in our advisory services. And we believe we are going to see many more opportunities. And it is our hope in many of these opportunities, not only will it be an opportunity in terms of advice or possibly Aladdin assignment. In many of these opportunities it will be, it will allow us to enter into an Asset Management assignment too.

So the intersecting of Solutions, Advisory, and Asset Management is more integrated and stronger today than it's ever been. Paul mentioned our cash management. Obviously liquidity and liquidity business is on everyone's mind. It is a big issue, we spend a lot of management time making sure that we are providing the most, the best product for our clients. It was noted in our fourth quarter that we do have those two small Asset Management cash strategy funds that we are working to provide liquidity to our clients, and we did take some charges in the fourth quarter. We feel very good about the future of that and working and resolving it alongside with the clients. But it's fair for me to say, the majority of our $230 billion of liquidity business is as strong if not stronger than ever. As evidence of $19 billion of new cash flow into this year has really given another indication to everyone that our business is strong in cash management and getting stronger. Our market share in 2007 and going into 2008 picked up remarkably in our cash management business.

The one thing of note, we had our best quarter ever in equity flows. To me, this is the greatest indication of what the new model of BlackRock is. We had $11 billion of equity flows in the fourth quarter. And I would tell you the majority of these flows were in our retail mutual funds, domestically and globally. And it is another indication of our brand recognition. So this is a combination of obviously performance, but one of the things that we struggled, one of the big issues we had when we announced the MLIM merger was the Merrill Lynch name was a larger brand name in the retail space. We have made huge progress in that. In April of this year we are going to drop the hyphenated name globally in our mutual fund platform, and it will just be the BlackRock fund family. And we are very excited about that, and we feel we are prepared for that today. And that will be a big event for all of us, but these flows in equities, these flows in our mutual fund platform is indicative that the BlackRock brand name is growing and growing very strongly.

I would like to note some of the issue related to fixed income. We did have outflows in fixed income. Some of the outflows was rebalancing at a fixed income into other products, and then we lost about 4-odd billion dollars with three or four clients, some of it was a restructuring with an insurance company assignment that they put the assets back on to the general account, away from a separate account. The other assignments were M&A related where the clients had to redeploy the monies that we were managing for them for these M&A opportunities that they had.

And so there's nothing systemic there. Actually our performance in the fourth quarter was strong. I am told, I don't have this finalized yet, we are going to have – our one and three year numbers are going to be probably in the first quartile in fixed income, and that's being basically flat to up a little last year. And so it really indicates the diversity, or the variance in terms of returns that so many people had in fixed income in 2007. But we expect to continue to see some very large changes in asset allocation in 2008.

Other than fear, other than worries, it is our opinion that a ten-year Treasury is a very difficult return to make any long-term investment decisions. But it's safe and you could be well protected in doing that. And so I'm not here to suggest that rates are not going to go any lower in intermediate area of the curve. But I will tell you at a 373, that's representing less and less value. But with the U.S. equity markets and global equity markets falling as much as they have, it is a safe place to put money. We will be a participant in that, in the short run by winning assignments there. We have shown with our $19 billion growth in cash management in the first few weeks of this year. People are still flooding a lot of cash into liquidity. As Paul suggested, we should not monetize this type of growth rate in liquidity. On the other hand, we do believe, as we continue to roll out more and more products, we'll be a participant in some of that redeployment of monies out of short-term assets into some longer-dated assignments.

The one other thing of particular note in the fourth quarter of 2007, and I think we'll – well, I know we are continuing that in 2008, is the opportunistic investing that we have done with our investors. We raised about $4.5 billion in two distressed products in the alternative space. We are about to launch another product that is in the mortgage related area to take advantage of dislocation in the mortgage world. And we see huge opportunities for BlackRock on behalf of our clients in investing the monies.

I would like to also state one differentiating feature that is giving us a lot of opportunity with our clients. BlackRock will not invest any of our capital for propriety trading. We'll not invest any of our capital to invest in things that we think are cheap. We use all our capital to invest alongside as a fiduciary with our clients.

And so as we roll out these products, we expect our clients are going to look for us to invest 1 to 5% predominantly, but at least 5% of the investment pool, and we'll continue to do that. But we are very proud and we believe we very much differentiated ourself from the majority of organizations that we do not do proprietary trading. Even though we see these opportunities, even though we believe they possess some great income opportunities, we believe the greater income opportunities working alongside our clients, suggesting these opportunities, investing alongside with them and working alongside with them. And so there's not one instance where BlackRock has a fiduciary conflict. And this is a very, very important differentiation as we roll out more and more products and as we work more and more with our clients.

I would like to just note that one of the other big issues when we rolled out the Merrill Lynch transaction that, some of the issues were: could we continue to build our relationships with a Merrill Lynch retail system? With one year totally behind us, our market share increased the with the Merrill Lynch system. We are working alongside with the management team of Merrill Lynch in terms of finding new opportunities, investing for their clients, and taking advantage of the opportunities that BlackRock can provide for them.

The other very, very important issue is our third party retail distribution. And it's fair to say for us we made huge progress in terms of the flows. A lot of our fourth quarter flows were third party distribution. And so we are starting to see momentum picking up because of the third party products and third party relationships that we have. And the last thing I just would like to bring up is obviously we've had a pretty large setback in the equity markets year-to-date. We believe we'll continue to have very volatile markets in the next quarter or so.

We do have are a long-term constructive view on the equity markets, but the intermediate term we are very concerned, and I would just caution everybody. When you have these volatile markets, you should expect people to defer, delay decisions. This happens every time, and I'd like to just remind everybody of that. Actually in the beginning of this quarter, we're actually seeing quite a few decisions that I talked about, the issues we had around our advisory services. So we are winning a lot of assignments on the advisory side. We are seeing huge opportunities in terms of RFPs, but I just want to warn everybody and I don't have any information that's telling me it is going to happen again but historically we have seen delays in decision-making during very volatile markets.

So 2008, we are very well positioned. We think we are going to have some great opportunities in terms of building out our relationships with our clients. I am very excited about the build out of the BlackRock brand on a global basis. We are still very interested in building out our product base on a global basis. Joining us this week was a whole new European equity team that we brought on Board the end of last year and they started this week. We are looking at other opportunities of bringing on more product people to enhance our position in products worldwide. And we do believe, and I'm not suggesting anything will happen, but we do believe there will be large M&A opportunities for BlackRock, at least for us to see, and history will tell you most of the time we walk away from the majority of them.

And if we happen to see something that works alongside of our Quellos transaction, works alongside of our State Street Research transaction or MLIM, we would go ahead and do it. We are not interested in doing transactions for accretion. We are only interested in doing transaction that will build out our presence on a global basis. So I promise you we are not doing – we would not do anything just for the sake of doing something because it is accretive, where we would only do it if it is lasting accretive. And the only way it is lasting accretive if it is an enhancement of product or enhanced in distribution.

The last thing I would like to welcome everybody from our Quellos transaction on board. It has been a spectacular first quarter with our team. We've seen huge synergies together with our BlackRock alternative advisory platform. Bryan White as our leader from Quellos now leading that effort has done a great job of integrating our teams. We are seeing huge opportunities in our fund-to-fund platforms, in private equity, and in hedge funds. And we are extremely happy with how we are doing in that integration. And obviously we are very happy and very excited of the continuation of our build-out of our overall global platform.

Last I'd just like to thank all of the BlackRock employees for an incredible year. I'd like to thank everyone for all of the hard work. This was not an easy year. I don't want to suggest that this is easy sailing for us. It was a very, very difficult year in terms of family life/work, balance. A lot of people worked extra hard to do what we have done this year. A lot of people worked beyond the measure to making sure that we achieve these results that we did. And it was the overall culture, the overall synergies of the overall firm. It was the team effort by everyone that allowed us to have these results.

I would like to thank all our clients in terms of working alongside with us. They entrusted us with lots of money, they entrusted us with a lot of issues related to decisions on behalf of them. And I believe we earned their respect in 2007, and I do believe we have that respect going into 2008 with our client base. Thank you everybody. I'll open it up for questions.
Your first question comes from William Katz of Buckingham Research.

Thank you, and good morning, and a very comprehensive update so thank you for that. I just wanted to talk about the fixed income business for a moment. If you look back over the last several quarters and maybe the genesis of the transaction, it does seem like the growth rate has slowed sharply, and not just because of lower large numbers. Larry, I was just curious, are we at the end of the cycle? I mean, I appreciate we're staying in the long end of the bond, but could there be a more decisive rotation to equities? And are you fully prepared to capture that if that were to happen?

Well, I think that's what I was trying to say, the 370, whatever. For the ten-year, I think we are going to see – and this is why in the long run we are very constructive on equities. I think you're going to see a very large rotation into equities, be it from cash or intermediate bonds. With the bond market rallying so much and equity market falling, you're going to see some really significant rebalancing from a lot of pension plans. And so we still see a lot of growth, Bill, in the global area. And the domestic side I think we're going to see a big rotation over the course of the next few years.

And to answer your question in terms of, are we going to be able to take advantage of it? I would say not fully yet. But I would say we are very well prepared and we are going to get prepared for that rotation. Our performance in equities as we noted in our release was very strong. You know, our global equity platform that we were nurturing, our global equity product had an extraordinary year last year. And, you know, if we continue to do that we'll be very prepared to take on some very large flows in terms of global equities. I discussed about our new team in European equities that we are enhancing. Our U.S. equity teams also had some very good years. Our global opportunity fund had one of the most remarkable years ever on a $40 billion platform.

And so the answer to your question, Bill, I wouldn't say we are fully prepared yet, because I would never say that. But I think we are certainly a lot more prepared than we've ever been before. But I don't think it'll be that dire. I still believe a lot of people will need to be in fixed income. And so I don't think it's going to be this gigantic rotation, but the trends will be a rotation from fixed to equities.
Okay. Thank you. And second question I have is: you mentioned that about half your pre-tax income came from outside the United States. Can you give me what the revenue mix was, please?
Bill, I gave you that at this point in time, but the revenue mix at this point in time I'm not in a position to say. But we may in effect disclose something along that in the year in the 10-K.

Okay. And then just a couple of more housekeeping items. I think you're out marketing, if you haven't closed already, a closed-end fund. Any sort of assessment of how successful that is, what the appetite is for that kind of product right now?

Well, it's in the marketing period now and I don't think I'm allowed to talk about it. I have Bob Connolly telling me I can't talk about it for SEC reasons. So it is in the market; it's going to be small. But we expect it to be small. I would tell you right now I believe this closed-end market is digesting huge flows in 2007, and one should expect the digestion will take some quarters. So I don't think we're going to see the huge inflows of money in closed-end funds as we did last year.
Okay. And then just in terms of the comp-to-revenue guidance. I was listening, but were you reflecting the increase from the fourth quarter, or from '07 into '08?

It was really more a '07 piece. Fourth quarter performance fees were obviously much higher deferred comp . But some of our other programs also had higher deferred comp to allocation. So it was more significantly felt in fourth quarter and it's rolling into '07 by that amount that I discussed.
Okay. And then just finally, . It looks like you had a little relief on the tax rate sequentially?
Yes.
Is that a reasonable run rate on a go-forward basis?
I think that around 35.5 is not an unreasonable number forward.
Okay. Thank you.
Your next question comes from Christopher Spahr of Deutsche Bank.
Hi, Chris, happy new year.
Happy new year. Good morning. I just wondering if you maybe just give a little bit of color on how we should think about the performance fees going forward both on a year-over-year basis and .

I never ask anyone to do any monetization of performance fees. We had an extraordinary year in performance fees. Our fixed income hedge funds navigated very carefully in this credit crisis. We had one fund that was up extraordinarily well. And then if you look at some of our hedge fund products, they're heavily oriented towards energy and commodities. I don't have to tell you what energy and commodities have done. And so we really benefited because of the type of hedge fund products that we have.

In addition, we had some extraordinary performance fees in real estate because we sold a bunch of real estate in the third and fourth quarter on behalf of our clients. And we took some performance fees when we wanted to take some of the risk down in our real estate platform. And so we expect we're well positioned again in 2008 to take advantage of these global opportunities in terms of our hedge funds. And as we discussed, we raised a lot more hedge funds and products in the fourth quarter. So obviously we don't forecast or tell anyone what's going to happen in 2008 related to hedge funds. But what I can say as we are growing out our alternative platform, we are certainly building out a more diversified base of alternative products that have performance-based fees.
But I guess the fees were up about 44% the last couple of years each year, so I'm just wondering like if...
It's because we're rolling out more and more products, and fortunately we've been right in those rollout of products.
Sure.

And we saw favorable markets. I mean, it's hard to tell you that you can automatically look at what we did this year and say, wow, you've increased the last couple of years. Could you run an increase when you're looking at a market that's down pretty substantially to start the new year?
Okay. And then finally advisory revenues per average AUM by asset class, appear to be higher across all asset classes. So I just wonder if you can give color about the sustainability of those.

The revenues were up as you probably saw across all asset classes, largely because we've had pretty sizeable organic growth across all asset classes, and you also had if you kind of looked at our numbers, pretty sizeable market contributions. I think the key here is, if you look at the equities and in certain of the alternative products, some of those market contributions were pretty sizeable. So if it was to me, I would say that if you look at the various ratios – 130 billion of organic growth versus about 70 billion of market – that you can automatically kind of look at those percentages. And I think you can apply those same ratios and try to see what was the revenue growth X market or on a quarter basis.
Okay. Thank you very much.
Your next question comes from Douglas Sipkin of Wachovia.
Hi, Doug.

Hi, good morning and happy new year. Just a couple of quick follow-ups drilling down on I guess the individual revenues for the asset products a little bit more. Just specifically honing in on the alternatives, the 134 million number. I mean, how much of that includes performance fees for this quarter? I mean, I'm trying to just think about that number, trying to gauge sort of a normalized level for that alternative revenue number. And then also as it relates to the cash management, I would imagine then you guys are recognizing revenues in there on assets that you're not reporting. So also how much of that would you attribute to maybe temporary type of stuff? I'm just trying to gauge what sort of the run rate for base fees would be into 2008?

Well, actually, rather than looking on a by-product basis because we don't get into all of these pieces until we file the K, what I can tell you is obviously if you look at our investment advisory base fees that we reported versus our performance fees, that'll give you a pretty good idea of what I would tend to call more recurring, the advisory fee total. And as to temporary assignments, Doug? I mean, really they're just not significant enough for me to sit down there and tell you that I have all those numbers handy. They're not going to...
Right.
...really a run rate.
Okay. So when I look at that 1.16, I mean, that's as true as I guess we're going to see I guess going forward, unless obviously the assets change dramatically.
I think that is a fair total to report on a recurring basis before obviously the implications of market.

Okay. And then obviously in conjunction with your comments about the bond yields being so low. With the dramatic growth that you guys have seen in the cash management business, I mean, are you taking more steps – I mean, are you implementing more procedures to try to make sure that you guys capture some of that rebalancing out of cash management when it does happen? I know obviously a very strong quarter for equities. But it seemed like most of it you highlighted came on the retail side. How should we be thinking about your ability to capture that liquidity assets on the equity on the institutional side whenever, hopefully, this allocation comes for the market's sake?

The way I would look at this, I mean, it is very hard to know where the clients will be deciding and how they will be deciding. But I'll tell you what BlackRock has is maybe the best opportunity. If you have heard us talk about how we run our business, I mean, the way we view one BlackRock and how we look at our clients. The way we run our marketing and our sales and support personnel, our clients know and our people that support our clients know every product and every relationship. So they are recognizing and understand how much a client who might be in long-dated fixed income or long-dated equity also has with respect to our institutional balances and our money market funds.

I think we are working with our clients all the time, everyday to understand that total exposure. So we're probably better positioned to work with them and understand, if they're looking for rotational opportunities, where we can then in effect provide the kind of product that they're looking for. It's just hard to say a percentage. I don't think anyone will really know. Many of our large institutional clients also participate in the direct markets in the money market side. They may choose to rotate into some of those areas, but I do think we're better positioned to capture those assets, if they are re-allocated, than anybody else.

Great. And then just finally if you could just reiterate. I think you provided some color around any impact you had from liquidity funds this quarter for supporting some of your money market products.

Really, there was no impact. I mean for all intents and purposes, while we had sustained as I said in my notes of outflows in the fourth quarter, we actually had 7 billion of those outflows on the last day of the year. every year.
I'm talking from a revenue standpoint I guess as it relates to maybe one of your non-2a-7 funds.
Oh, you mean revenue implications?
Yes.
We have been waving fees on those products for the last six months. There is no revenue implications that you have to worry about.
Okay. Okay, great. Thanks a lot, and very nice quarter.
Thank you.
Your next question will be from Craig Siegenthaler of Credit Suisse.
Hello, Craig.

Hi, actually it's Tom Gallagher here. I just wanted to ask a quick one, and then Craig's going to have a few more detailed ones. Larry, just noticed this morning Amback put on review for downgrade by Moody's, and it looks like all bonds insured by them put on review.
Yes.

Now, just curious to get your view on – I guess you could probably go on for a while about a discussion of reverberation to the fixed income markets from something like this. But just curious on your take on this, whether you see it having a meaningful impact on your business positively, negatively. Can you give a little color on that? Thanks.

I don't know anything directly. Positively, I think, I think all this turmoil on the marketplace is causing clients worldwide to readdress who they are dealing with. Having -being well positioned in terms of the risk management, I think we are going to be a beneficiary in 2008 of the market turmoil. I also do believe clients are going to be looking to dealing with larger capitalized, larger firms, more global firms.

So I think the unraveling of some of these mono lines and continuation of credit deterioration, relative to the world is good for BlackRock. It is probably absolutely bad for all of us in a little ways. Obviously with these companies imploding in terms of the mono lines, it is going to have a real impact on potentially the muni market. Certainly a lot of potential in terms of the housing market and the mortgage insurance market. So it is going to have some large implications, and I don't know how they are going to fill out.
